dataset.title: SGS-LTER CO2 Elevation Study: OTC summer plus fall total harvest data on the Central Plains Experimental Range, Nunn, Colorado, USA 1997 - 2001

para.literalLayout: Above-ground plant material was harvested in July (PSC) and Oct. in five years of CO2 enrichment in Open-top-chambers. There was a consistent increase in plant productivity in the elevated CO2 chambers.

Data sets were provided by the Shortgrass Steppe Long Term Ecological Research group, a partnership between Colorado State University, United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, and the U.S. Forest Service Pawnee National Grassland. This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant No. 1027319

Data sets were provided by the Shortgrass Steppe Long Term Ecological Research group, a partnership between Colorado State University, United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, and the U.S. Forest Service Pawnee National Grassland. Significant funding for these data was provided by the National Science Foundation Long Term Ecological Research program (NSF Grant Number DEB-0217631).

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The Short Grass Steppe site encompasses a large portion of the Colorado Piedmont Section of the western Great Plains. The extent is defined as the boundaries of the Central Plains Experimental Range (CPER). The CPER has a single ownership and landuse (livestock grazing). The PNG is characterized by a mosaic of ownership and land use. Ownership includes federal, state or private and land use consists of livestock grazing or row-crops. There are NGO conservation groups that exert influence over the area, particularly on federal lands.

section.title: Methods for this dataset
section.para: All aboveground plant biomass data presented herein were from samples collected in the southern half of the chambers. During the period of peak standing phytomass (late July), a metal wire grid containing fifty-six 40.5 3 15.3 cm quadrats (3.46 m2 total) was placed over the south half of each plot and vegetation in every other quadrat (28 quadrats) was clipped to the crown, separated by species, dried at 608C, and weighed. This defoliation protocol, which removed 50% of the green vegetation and represents defoliation by cattle that is intermediate between moderate and heavy grazing practices (Klipple and Costello 1960, Milchunas et al. 1988, 1995), was incorporated into the CO2-treatment experimental design primarily as a means to represent the nominal grazing conditions for these grasslands. In autumn, aboveground phytomass was harvested in all 56 quadrats; weights from the July harvest were combined with this latter one to determine total seasonal productivity for the experimental area. The pattern was reversed the following year; quadrats that had not been clipped the previous summer were clipped at peak standing phytomass, and all quadrats harvested in the autumn. Annual alternation of the small grids that received or did not receive the defoliation during a particular growing season allowed for cycles of ‘‘restfrom- defoliation.’’ The October final harvest involved only senescent shoot material. Phytomass in the northern half of the chambers was defoliated at ;2 cm height in October so that plant cover throughout the chamber was comparable at the beginning and end of each growing season. The northern half of the chamber was used for trace gas flux and other measurements, which are reported elsewhere (Mosier et al. 2002).

attribute.attributeDefinition: typical growing season from April to October

textDomain.definition: typical growing season from April to October

attribute.attributeDefinition: Treatment plots were covered with chamber pumped with elevated CO2 levels or pumped ambient air. Control plots were not under a chanmber.

textDomain.definition: Treatment plots were covered with chamber pumped with elevated CO2 levels or pumped ambient air. Control plots were not under a chanmber.
textDomain.pattern: a=ambient CO2 open-top-chamber; h=elevated (720ppm) CO2 OTC; c=nonchambered control

ns2:unit.ns2:description: megajoules per square meter per day

ns2:unit.ns2:description: moles of substance per meter squared per day

ns2:unit.name: dimensionless
ns2:unit.ns2:description: a designation asserting the absence of an associated unit

ns2:unit.name: acre
ns2:unit.ns2:description: 1 acre = 4046.8564 square meters or 1 hectare = 2.4710 acres

ns2:unit.name: bushelsPerAcre
ns2:unit.ns2:description: bushels per acre -- 1 bushel = 35.23907 liters/1 acre = 4046.8564 squareMeters

ns2:unit.name: degree
ns2:unit.ns2:description: 360 degrees comprise a unit circle; degrees used for angle and slope

ns2:unit.name: fahrenheit
ns2:unit.ns2:description: An obsolescent unit of temperature still used in popular meteorology

ns2:unit.ns2:description: grams Per Centimeter Squared Per Second

ns2:unit.name: langleys
ns2:unit.ns2:description: 1 langley= 4.187 Joules per square centimeter; langley per day=0.4846 W per square meter; (W=1 Joule per sec)

ns2:unit.name: megaJoulesPerSquareMeter
ns2:unit.ns2:description: A measure of solar radiation energy per unit area

ns2:unit.name: micromolePerMeterSquaredPerSecond
ns2:unit.ns2:description: micromole per meter squared per second

ns2:unit.name: molePerMeterSquaredPerSecond
ns2:unit.ns2:description: SI unit of areal density rate

ns2:unit.name: nominalDay
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one day excluding leap seconds, 86400 seconds

ns2:unit.name: nominalHour
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one hour excluding leap seconds, 3600 seconds

ns2:unit.name: nominalLeapYear
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one 366 day year excluding leap seconds, 31622400 seconds

ns2:unit.name: nominalMinute
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one minute excluding leap seconds, 60 seconds

ns2:unit.name: nominalWeek
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one day excluding leap seconds, 604800 seconds

ns2:unit.name: nominalYear
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one year excluding leap seconds and leap days, 31536000 seconds

ns2:unit.name: partPerMillion
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as parts per million (1:1000000)

ns2:unit.name: partsPerMillion
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as parts per million (1:1000000)

ns2:unit.name: percent
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)

ns2:unit.name: tonnePerHectare
ns2:unit.ns2:description: metric ton or tonne per hectare
